name: StreamSubscription
comment:
A control object for the subscription on a angular/angular.Stream.

When you subscribe on a angular/angular.Stream using angular/angular.Stream.listen, a angular/angular.StreamSubscription object is returned. This object is used to later unsubscribe again, or to temporarily pause the stream's events.

cancel.name: cancel
cancel.comment:
Cancels this subscription. It will no longer receive events.

If an event is currently firing, this unsubscription will only take effect after all subscribers have received the current event.

Returns a future if the cancel-operation is not completed synchronously. Otherwise returns null.

onData.name: onData
onData.comment: Set or override the data event handler of this subscription.

onError.name: onError
onError.comment:
Set or override the error event handler of this subscription.

This method overrides the handler that has been set at the invocation of angular/dart-async.Stream.listen.

onDone.name: onDone
onDone.comment: Set or override the done event handler of this subscription.

pause.name: pause
pause.comment:
Request that the stream pauses events until further notice.

If angular/angular.StreamSubscription.pause.resumeSignal is provided, the stream will undo the pause when the future completes. If the future completes with an error, it will not be handled!

A call to angular/angular.StreamSubscription.resume will also undo a pause.

If the subscription is paused more than once, an equal number of resumes must be performed to resume the stream.

Currently DOM streams silently drop events when the stream is paused. This is a bug and will be fixed.

asFuture.name: asFuture
asFuture.comment:
Returns a future that handles the angular/angular.StreamSubscription.onDone and angular/angular.StreamSubscription.onError callbacks.

This method overwrites the existing angular/angular.StreamSubscription.onDone and angular/angular.StreamSubscription.onError callbacks with new ones that complete the returned future.

In case of an error the subscription will automatically cancel (even when it was listening with cancelOnError set to false).

In case of a done event the future completes with the given angular/angular.StreamSubscription.asFuture.futureValue.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides angular/angular.StreamSubscription.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and angular/angular.StreamSubscription.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the angular/angular.StreamSubscription.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
angular/angular.StreamSubscription.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to angular/angular.StreamSubscription.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If angular/angular.StreamSubscription.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of angular/angular.StreamSubscription.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
